instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPBUS_G3: What is PPBUS_G3? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H. When you see PPBUS_G3, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

Have this board which had one USB-c with 5V looping <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and other with no voltage <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. Replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and got 5V voltage on both USB-C ports.
Replaced <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> thinking that it may be faulty too, but still stuck at 5V


<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3_CHGR</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
F7000 - 2.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>P5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 2.8V

<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>TBA_BOOT1</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>TBA_BOOT2</SIGNAL> - 1.8V

L7670 - 2.8V

Where I should be looking? Any suggestions?


Something I have never come across before. One of the CD3215C chips I have replaced has different ID under the printed part. Have anyone seems anything like this?
Cannot make up the ID, but seems like TPS series used for usb-c controllers on laptops.

[ATTACH type="full"]59343[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3</SIGNAL> - 3.4V"
Do you mean 3.4V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

Also I'm not sure if you really changed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> two times...

Post LDO voltages and diode mode on both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Probably I wasn't clear, I have not changed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> twice.  I replaced both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> I meant.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3</SIGNAL> - 3.4V  - I am sure I read it 3.3V bit earlier, Now it shows 2.2V - 0.5 Diode mode

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V - 0.51 in diode mode
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V - 0.51 in diode mode

What are other LDO voltages?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
"I replaced both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> I meant."
I supposed that, but you only mentioned <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> replacement two times (re-read first post); I wanted to be sure.
Post accurate information for the future.

"What are other LDO voltages?"
There are 4 LDOs; 1V1, 2x 1V8, 3V3.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Got it, sorry for the typo there.

LDO voltages are;
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V - 0.5
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V - 0.5
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V - 0.5
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V - 0.5

Thanks Again

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Missing 1V1 LDO points to bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.
You should check voltage there when the charger is connected to corresponding port.
Really strange to have exactly 0.500 diode mode reading on all LDOs, never saw that.

Be aware of fake/remarked "new" CD 3215 chips...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Sorry I was rounding to decimals there, my bad. 

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 63049, member: 682"]
You should check voltage there when the charger is connected to corresponding port.
[/QUOTE]
Yes checked the both 1.1 and 1.8 voltages by swapping between 2 ports.

Usually, 5V is when usb-c chips are not communicating right? I will swap that "remarked" chip

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Replaced the chip with one from the same batch. Same suspicious quality. Still no change from 5.13V on both ports

There is something new though. Seems like I have lost 1.8 LDOA and PP3V3 on the newly replaced chip <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/B - 3.41V - 0.364 - Reboots every 3-5sec

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.796V - 0.476 - Stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.801V - 0.472   - Reboots every 3-5sec
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.824V - 0.508
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 0.016V - 0.502

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>B_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V - 0.502

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.380V - 0.509  - Reboots every 3-5sec
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.016V - 0.540


I reflowed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> thinking it may not have settled well, but still same readings. Perhaps this whole batch is bad, what are the odds of that.

Unfortunately, this is my last 5 in this batch I ordered from [URL='https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000190094556.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.27424c4d7u5guN']Professional BGA chip factory[/URL]. Which reminds me that I need to order more, these <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> are never enough.
Any suggestions on a good supplier?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
You should test buying 2 chips from different stores.
Do NOT buy high quantity before assure the quality...

BTW, go for the port which doesn't restart first.
The restart possibly means that port is good and board tries to start; other issue (apart of USB-C) makes the board restarts.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message: When you say go for it, replace the CD3215which doesn't restart and retest?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message: That is the one you must replace first...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Thanks for all of your help 2informaticos. I am giving up on this one. 
I have replaced that chip and now I am getting completely different readings with high heat signature on the replaced <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>, while still stuck at 5V. 
Additionally, I also detect a short on <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>. Checked <CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR> and is reading fine. 

Either this whole batch of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is busted or there is something else there which is giving me inconsistent values.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on USB-C after replaced charging chips. No liquid signs.
threads.message:
Be aware of marking codes.
Original chips have a nice engraved marking, very easy to read.
Fake/remarked chips have serigrafied marking, almost impossible to read; many times needs to wet the chip with alcohol, to make code visible.
